author: Zapp_Brannigan
title: Perfect on every level
review:
At last, Lego has finally released another bank. This is the third bank in the history of the City/Town theme. To my knowledge, the previous banks had average to poor reception; 1490 released in 1990 has an average rating of 2.9/5, and 6566 released in 1997 has an average rating of 3.3/5. Luckily, this is quite a decent bank, and I will explain why shortly.

The build to this set is fairly straightforward; there is nothing fancy or challenging. You can enjoy your set after a build time of about an hour.

To begin with, this set includes four minifigures: a robber, police officer, bank teller, and security guard/van driver. Accessories include a crowbar, two money pieces, two gold pieces, two safes, burlap sack, four green suitcases, dolly, and walkie-talkie. Vehicles include a security van, police cruiser, and motorcycle (with new design). The van stores the two safes and four suitcases, and there are doors on the left, right, and rear of the van which allow access to its interior. The roof of the van can also be taken off to play inside it.

I was extremely impressed with how much detail the bank has. The exterior of the bank has two "BANK" signs, an ATM, an alarm (to the extreme right), a sun roof, and a pipe where the robber escapes. The overall design of the bank is aesthetically pleasing, and the colour scheme of yellow, grey, and navy blue is very nice. The building is modular; you can take the second floor off.

When you enter the bank, the first floor has a flower pot, chair, desk with computer, clock, cabinet, cup, and a small red shelf where papers are stored.

The second floor is very interesting. This is the actual vault room where money and gold are stored. Here, there is a vault door, and behind the door is a shelf for the money and gold. Lastly, there is another flower pot identical to the one on the first floor. The robber enters/escapes the bank via the opening sun roof and the pipe located on the left side of the bank.

Overall, this is an excellent set worth buying. It is nice how Lego has released another bank. I'm slightly disappointed with the price though. At $64.99 CAD, it can be slightly cheaper. Other than that, I am very satisfied and I suggest all City fans get it as well.

author: SgtSmash
title: This is a good place for a stick up!
review:
The Bank & Money Transfer is a cool little set, packed with a ton of features, play value, rare brick pieces, and is a welcome addition, perhaps long overdue. 

 

I had a good time building this set with my daughter, and the build didn't take very long, maybe an hour or so at best. I really enjoy the end result, with the bank building of course being my favorite part. I was really impressed with the color selection and overall design that Lego put into it. While the building isn't all that large, it seems to follow the current trend of narrow yet tall two-story buildings (ala City Corner) that can easily fit just about anywhere in your town without the need to re-arrange road/base plates.

 

The computer downstairs even has a different screen for once, and the design of the safe upstairs was well thought out. I like the gold bricks, and the cash that is included. The skylight is a decent feature as well. Interestingly enough is the ATM machine out front which detaches from the building, and only sits in the space provided. The clock for the interior is on the other side of the machine, so if you take out the ATM, you get the clock too. My assumption is that this floating design is for when the robber(s) try to jack the ATM machine and rip it out of the wall. Did the Lego designers see one too many episodes of COPS?

 

The bank teller has the same outfit included in a few recent sets, like the Grand Emporium, but appears to have a new braided hair design. The burglar comes with a cool backpack, with room to stuff cash and gold bricks, and also comes with a red crowbar, to match his red motorbike(?). I would have maybe colored the crowbar differently, as it is reminiscent of a snake, but I digress. 

 

The police car seems to be a station wagon design, but there is no backseat. It would have been a welcome feature had Lego designed the police car like the taxi which comes with the City Train Station #7937, with room for a backseat for the burglar to sit in after getting apprehended. The security van was well thought out, with slots for the money bags, as well as two safes and "sliding" doors which I don't think I've seen before. I really like the new powder blue police outfit which the security guard is wearing too.

 

On a side note, there's been quite a bit of speculation and not a whole lot of news about what the next Modular Building will be. Some were hoping it would be a bank, but I guess that question has now been answered. Although it never stopped Lego from creating the "Fire Brigade" building, despite there being an existing Fire Station...but my guess is that the next mod building will be a post office, or perhaps a Hospital? Not sure, but that would be cool. Hopefully it will be something that hasn't been offered yet.

author: Naylus
title: Brick-Banking!
review:
It is possible, that set #3661 is another reminder of old good Lego City sets, released many years ago. A small building with yellow walls looks simple enough, but still pretty detailed.

The Building:

  • The ground floor includes a hallway with a chair, a plant pot and a modern desk (with alarm button) for the bank employee. One of the interesting details is the computer, though it was released with other sets before. Outside is the banking terminal, that can be destroyed/removed/wrenched out by the burglars or... anyone who, as You believe, could do that.
  • The first floor also includes the plant pot, as well as a large safe with golden plates. I really like the glass ceiling here, that also acts as a "door" for the uninvited guests. A nice addition to the playability actually. Some details have pictures and don't use stickers here. Both floors have tubes, that a burglar can climb up to get to the Bank.

The Transport:

  • The police car is not much special, but still a very good addition to your City if You don't have one. However it uses plenty of stickers.
  • The large van looks just awesome. It has two vaults, that can be removed from the car, as well as a special depository for the four (4) green suitcases (and a red cart for them).

#3661 has a very nice selection of Minifigs:

  • A Bank Employee - a nice lady with brown hair from Prince of Persia Lego series. Looks good, no doubt.
  • A Bank Security Officer - with blue uniform and white cap.
  • A Police Officer - You are already familiar with him.
  • A Burglar - the guy with a crowbar and a bag with Lego currency...

In other words - the set is really diverse in details and ideas for both games and building. The Bank would fit perfectly into any street of your Lego Town.

author: Fire6
title: Another Nice Addition to the City
review:
I have been interested in this set since the very first pictures were released. Though this a police/emergency services set, the bank and armored truck provides a neat addition to any city and is worth getting even by those who are tired of the plethora of emergency services sets.


The Police Car
The police car is a nice and simple car that provides another variant to the many different types of police vehicles present. The car comes with a sticker designating it #6 which ties it well well the rest of the 2011 police sets.

The Crook

The crook comes with the now standard crook backpack and crowbar along with a RED dirt bike which is a nice addition to the ORANGE dirt bike provided with the Prisoner Transport set. the minifigure head is also different than the heads provided with the previously mentioned Prisoner Transport and the Police Minifigure Collection.

The Armored Car

The Armored Car is visually a great vehicle and provides a lot of play options for the younger owners. The Armored Car is designed very will and comes with a hand-truck to transport either the four green suitcases provided or the two safes provided. The Armored Car comes with two side doors and a back door which along with the two removable roof sections provides easy access to the interior of the vehicle.
The only complaint that I have about armored car is the minifigure provided to be the guard/driver. The back of the minifig torso has "POLICE" printed across it and it would have been nice if they would have provided a torso without the printing.

The Bank

The Bank is the primary reason that I purchased this set. When combined with City Corner
and the Toys R Us Store Front the Bank helps establish a Lego City not as focused focused on emergency services. The Bank is two stories and comes with multiple detail parts including a computer keyboard and screen on the first floor and a vault on the second floor. The vault door may be a bit fragile for the younger owners. The Bank provides a "storm drain" on the side for the Crooks to climb up the side of the bank and there is a hatch on the roof that allows the Crooks access to the vault on the second floor. On the front of the Bank there is a removable "ATM" machine for a larger range of play options for the younger owners.

The Pros

The Bank and the Armored Car are the two biggest Pros for the set though four minifigs is nice too.

The set has elements for both the younger owner who wants a versatile play setting and the AFOL who is interested in expanding their City and acquiring new vehicles/buildings

The Cons

The only major Con for many people will be the large number of stickers
A lessor issue is the fragile Vault Door

author: av8r1973
title: Finally - a great looking bank with loads of playability!
review:
After seeing this in the 2011 release announcement, it immediately went on my wish list.  We found it online in Taiwan for about the US retail price, so we picked it up.  My 3yo daughter built the cop car, my 5yo daughter built the bank by herself, and I built the armored car when they lost interest (attention span of a snow pea).

The color selection was thought out very well.  The navy blue bricks are a sharp contrast to the typical primary colors, and it could really be a bank's scheme.  The yellow elements are tastefully mixed in with lots of "glass" to make it a very modern building.  The color scheme carries through to the armored car, as does a new logo to the City theme (as far as I can tell).

Bank: Other reviews already discussed the bank in pretty good detail.  Standard 2-story structure with an open back.  No new elements here, but the elements are all useful.  The desk downstairs with a modern computer and coffee cup share the floor space with a potted plant.  I would like to have seen the ficus tree that came with the Town Plan used here, rather than the standard flowers, but it may have taken too much floor space.  The ATM outside is a nice touch, though it's not held in enough to withstand a blow to the building by a daughter's foot.  It does allow the included crook to steal it more easily.

Upstairs is a very nicely designed vault door.  The mounting method is a bit flimsy, but we'll see how it holds up (standard antenna with no upper support)  The vault stores the gold bricks (like the one that came with the 7288 Mobile Police Unit) and the cash.  Nice use of anchor bricks to give the appearance of more cash.

Police Car: Standard white car with blue stickers.  Not much to discuss here.  Though it looks like a station wagon, it must be a rear-engine one, as there is no storage in the back.  It would have been nice to find a place to put the included handheld radio.

Armored Car: Besides the cool looking bank, this is the star of the set.  It's an incredibly sturdy 6-lug wide truck with great proportions and realistic details.  Both sides have swing-up panels that expose storage for two safes.  The back opens for access to 4 bays for the included green cash suitcases.  Both 6x6 flat top panels easily come off to allow access inside, too.  The minifig is really a police torso with back printing.  A second security minifig would have been nice, since most armored cars have at least two guards.

Crook:  He was a standard crook wearing his prison stripes, but he rides a dirt bike for a getaway vehicle!  Cool, now I can have real motorcycle chases with the other police motorcycles.

Conclusion: I can see some armored truck heists in the near future, along with the bank robberies with this great addition to the City theme.  The two minor nits noted above aren't even worth reporting as a con, so I can't see any cons within this set. The price is a bit higher than I expected, but there are a lot of features and ingenious build techniques to compensate.  Highly recommended.

author: Jordy_Nieuwhoff
title: Very nice looking set
review:
Replace this text with your introduction.

Pros

  • The money delivery truck is well thought out. Nice little details. Different storage compartments for money suitcases and vaults.  
  • The ATM is nice done and easy to steal by the villain. But he needs to steal a big truck first.
  • The colours of the bank are very nice add to the city look.

Cons

  • The ATM can't be refilled from the inside. Is possible by raising the ATM by 1 plate. But than it is less easy to steal.
  • Construction of the big vault is not sturdy and has a big gab above.
  • The money walker is a police guy not a corporate. I already have 15 police minifigs of 135 citizens.
  • I still don't like the stands of the motorbikes.  

All with all a very good set with a lot of new stories that could be played.

author: sudorum
title: Not a likely candidate for a large heist..
review:
This is the first bank to be created in quite awhile by the Lego company. As far as rare pieces are concerned, the set is complete with three green suitcases, an open back pack, gray 1x4 pieces which are flat in the middle and studded on each end, and an oddity that appears to be a combo between a a 1x2 and a slanted flat piece. The set is divided into four bags with three instructions. The first set is for the police car and and the bike, the second set for the armored car, and the third for the bank itself. I suppose the instructions are somehow meant to make the build easier, but for me it's a pain because I'll have to search for multiple instructions for one set if a particular part is broken.
There isn't much to say about the police car other than it's the usual mundane build. The armored car is thankfully unique with a row of panels in the back to store the suitcases. The middle of the car is a storage for two disappointingly empty safes. The robber is also lacking in loot. Instead of  two bank notes being included in his pouch, one bill is attached to a studded piece of the same size. As for the bank itself, it's structurally sound. The bottom floor has a chair, a flower pot, a desk with a computer, and a cabinet with a paper storage on top. The top floor also has a flower pot and the vault which contains two shelves, only one of which has gold. The roof has a raising sky light which can be accessed by the side of the building via pipe. The atm on the outside of the bank is, to no surprise, totally empty, though it is flashy and well constructed. 
  Like all legos, this set has its fair share of decals. I wouldn't be surprised if the head honchos at Lego suddenly decided it's economically efficient to print no designs on minifigures and rely entirely on stickers. This may be hyperbole, but the set is good nonetheless. Buy it if you've got a few spare bucks to wave around. Now, if only they'd make a large bank compatible with Green Grocer...

author: AETerry
title: Bank & Money Transfer Review
review:
I've been chomping at the bit wanting to get this set and I knew it was over at my local Target, but it's taken a bit to feel I've the money, time and I finally decided to just order it from LEGO.com for the VIP points. Well worth the time I think and just a beautiful set to have.

 

Berrybrick's Review has a list of all the bank sets that LEGO has done over the year, there's more of them then I give credit for. But then I've only been counting the LEGO Bank set 1490 (yr. 1990) and then Bank set 6566 (yr. 1997) as proper Bank sets for a Lego Town or City. The others were for another theme or just a facade front that didn't really count.

 

For those on a budget and can't afford those huge $150 modular Town sets... this Bank set offers a far more affordable buy and build with a lot of good details to it, inside and outside. I'm just surprised by all the little details put into this set.

 

The set is also broken down so it's like you're building three different models. Starting off first with the Police Vehicle, a welcomed addition to the 2011 Police theme and sets I want to pick up for this year. Then it's the Armored Car which is better then another Armored Car set I got to go along with my Bank set 6566. It holds 4 green suit cases of money, 2 large safes and then it's dolley for transporting those pieces around with. The top of the Armored Car easily lifts off in two parts so you can get pieces in and out of it.

 

The final build is the bank itself with all of it's detail work and stickers, yes stickers. Love them or hate them, they are part of this set. My only complaint is that that the gold credit card piece, I'd have had printed instead of placing a sticker on it. The rest is fine.

 

4 Minifigures in all fill out this set, the Police Officer, the Bank Teller, the Armored Car Driver and then the Crook with his red motorcylce who climbs up a pole on the side of the bank and can get away for a speed chase.

 

There's just plenty and lots that can be done with this set for a City scene. I love it and am glad I was finally able to get around to getting it.

author: stagus
title: Nice City addition
review:
Slightly different angle for this review as I am an adult collector and city builder.  The build is a nice one.  The van is excellent with safes inside as well as the secure compartment for the suitcases (loaded with banking bonds no doubt).  It sits well within a city.  My main street has 4 of the modular builds so this is a good building to have as a lead out from the city centre due to it being two storey.  The best point about the police car is that it is 'number 6' so when the police helicopter is following the pursuit it is easily identifiable.

 

For younger builders I would think there is plenty of playablility.  Gold to be stolen from the vault....climb up the drain pipe to access the roof.....enter via glass panel or you could hijack the van and make off on the motorbike with the police in hot pursuit or you could crowbar the cash machine, etc, etc.

Pros

  • Nice build
  • Good city addition
  • Loads of playabilty
  • The security van is excellent

Cons

  • Quite pricey 

Conclusion

 

Good set, loads of playability for old and young alike and looks excellent in a city.  Just a wee bit expensive.

author: Berrus_Brickus
title: Hold 'em up!
review:
I ordered this from LEGO.com with the Seabed Strider and a couple handfuls of Collectable Minifigures. 

 

This is the seventh LEGO bank as far as I can tell, here are the others:

  • 1490 LEGO Bank (1990)-TOWN
  • 4608 Bank Breakout (2001)-Jack Stone
  • 4714 Gringott's Bank (2001)-Harry Potter
  • 4854 Doc Ock's Bank Robbery (2004)-Spiderman
  • 6566 Bank (1997)-TOWN
  • 1376 Spiderman Action Studio (2002)-Studios
  • 10217 Diagon Alley (2011)-Harry Potter

Box/Instructions

The first thing that I noticed about the box is that it was a lot shorter and wider than boxes for sets of this size (like Hagrid's Hut for you HP fans).  On the front of the box we get and image similar to the instructions, just a lot larger and with a limited/special edition banner.

There are three instruction booklets, one for the police car and motor-bike, one for the armored car, and lastly, one for the bank.

 

I did find one actual mistake in the instructions.  When building the armored car, it calls for a blue 1x4 beam, but it shows it in dark blue on one page.

That was the only actual mistake, but some of you might think of these as mistakes:

  • One of the last steps of building the armored car is to insert the two gray safes (or saves?), however on the last page of the book, we see them outside of the truck
  • On the horizontal bank sign, it only tells you to apply one sticker

Parts

This set has 405 pieces for $50 which isn't bad because:

  • The car and motor-bike themselves would be about $10, the armored a car about $15, and the bank about $30
  • It is limited edition
  • We get quite a few extra pieces!

Most of the parts are not printed.  For printed parts we have a new computer screen, a darkstone QWERTY keyboard, two $100 bills, and a clock.  I won't really complain about the stickers as they are fairly easy to apply, with the exception of the lisence plates.  I do wish that we could get the POLICE sticker printed next time as it is used very much in Police sets (so in about every other set ;) ).

Minifigures

The Officer: Standard black legs, average CITY Police torso (I thought that sombody said somthing about new backprinting!), a new face showing a large chin and a strange facial expression (kind of looks like he had an accident to me), and another white officer cap.  Fine except for the face.

The Bank Teller: Light gray legs, new gray female jacket w/ a purple scarf and pale pink shirt sticking out, New opened mouth female face (finally, they stopped using Mary Jane's!), and Tasmina's hairpiece.  She is perfect, except for Tasmina's hair. . . .

The Bank Transport Agent: Dark blue legs, new light blue police detective torso (w/ POLICE backprinting), a face w/ a brown beard, glasses and slightly crossed eyes, he also has the mini U.S. cap in a slightly new mould.  Fine except for the face.

The Criminal: Dark gray legs, same-old crook torso piece, new face with a brown stubble moustache, and a wide open mouth, and a standard black knit cap.  I actually hated this figure at first, but he became my favorite of the batch because he reminds me of Brickster's idiotic, cross-eyed henchmen!

The build

Not sure how long it took me, probably 50-min, give-or-take.  The build is simple enough and doesn't really use any new building techniques except for the ATM removal and I haven't seen the way that they placed the sign in an official set before.  My only complaint is that when building the armored car (a lot of the problems seem to be with this!), whel building the racks, they are supported with a bunch of random red and yellow pieces. It's fine though because after the truck is completed, only two of the yellow bricks are still visible and only when the doors are opened.

The completed model

A perfect expansion for the City Corner set which is a great set dedicated to everyday CITY life (which is becoming more common with LEGOs!).  The bank is a little smaller than I though, but that's fine.  It is still larger than the bus stop and skate shop, it's about the same size as the Pizzaria, which makes the scene look much better as before the restaurant towered over the other two buildings.

 

One complaint is that the crook's escape pole has to be turned 90 degrees to the right, otherwise the Bank must end the street.

The playability of this set is great, we have a bank, a POLICE car (I actually needed another one), a crook on a motor-bike, and three things for the notorius criminal to attack, the ATM, the safe, and the armored truck.

Summary

All in all, a great set! Oh sure there were a few problems with it, mostly on the armored car, but I love it anyways!

 

On the note of the list, I can say that it is better than the others because-

  • The Harry Potter ones aren't usable
  • The Spiderman ones are basically backdrops
  • The Jackstone one is overly juniorized
  • The TOWN ones are out of date

So yeah, get it if you're into CITY.

author: embee
title: nice set with lots of details
review:
From my point of view , it is a very nice set.
The collector's van is highly realistic, not lacking anything, nicely detailed.
Police car is lackign some details, it is a bit unfinished look, but it is a diferent type or a car, and i will tune it up a little bit.
The bike is red and it fits nicely to the collection of the dirt bikes.
For me the bank building is absolute winner in this set. Nicely detailed, reasonable size, nice colours and lovely fits to the city of Lego world.
And the best thing on this set was the price. I bought the set just for 29.99 euro.
What a bargain.
Keep brickin' everyone

author: JDLego
title: Best City Police Set Ever!
review: Bought this set not too long ago, and out of Police boat, Police headquarters, Police Minifigure Collection, Prisoner Transport, and Dog van which I own all of, and I got to say this one is the best police set I own, being special edition of course. Tons of playability and a fun build(Which was easy being modular build), its good for its money($49.99 US), comes with 405 pieces, 4 minfigures, and lots of cool(New) pieces! The secure van is awsome! can hold the safes, and green four new suitcases, and the minifigure is cool as well, police car is as usual,same but a good addition to your police force. Robber comes with new crowbar piece and new backpack that holds money. The bank teller is female with new ponytail hair piece. Comes with 2 gold bars, money and New credit card! The bank is detailed and cool, a good set to put in your city because lego hasnt made one in a while, so I would recommend getting this set before its gone, its special edition and a good set to play with and or add to your city! Good job Lego and have fun building!

author: Harmonious_Building
title: But plastic IS money.
review:
Between LEGO’s fixation with innumerable colossal police stations that would bring a tear to Joseph Stalin’s eye and harbour/marina sets that look good but I personally never buy because I would find them awkward to display (nothing else would be able to go on the side of the set that’s supposed to be “water”), the LEGO city sometimes finds itself a little lacking in civilian buildings that aren’t geared towards turning the town into an Orwellian dystopia. 2009’s City Corner (7641) went a long way towards boosting the local economy, and now we have a fantastic bank that not only looks good but counterbalances the police state that LEGO gets closer towards every year. True enough, Bank & Money Transfer is indeed classified under the “Police” subtheme and does feature a police car and police officer, but it’s a far cry from being an all-out “Police” set in the same way that the frightening Mobile Police Unit (7288) is. Seriously, you’ve got a problem when one of those starts rolling through town on a Sunday morning.

But enough about the failure of liberalism in LEGO city. Bank & Money Transfer comes with four Minifigs and a handful of great vehicles in addition to the bank building itself. Four Minifigs is definitely a great boon to any city display, but one can’t help but wonder why a businessman was not included as part of the count, although it is no great loss as you can get one with the Small Car (3177), City Minifig Collection (8401), or, heck, even Tripod Invader (7051).

I had never been particularly interested in city vehicles before, but the ones included in this set went a long way in changing my mind. The motorcycle is a standard build and nothing to crow about, but the police car and the armored car are absolutely great, and particular mention has to be given to the armored car, which not only looks good but has fantastic amount of utility to it as well. The safes and money carriers fit snugly in designated compartments at the back of the truck, and the whole design gives it a very sturdy feel that is completely appropriate for a vehicle that carried thousands of dollars in it on a routine basis. The driver Minifig is also very cool, dressed to look more like a rent-a-cop than in the serious black that the “real” police officers in LEGO city wear. I’ll bet you anything that he’s only three weeks from retirement, too.

The bank itself is also no slouch, both in terms of display and in terms of playability. At the front, there is an ATM whose panel is completely removable (not sure why), and the sleekness of the whole design is just gorgeous, setting it clearly apart from the less serious storefronts like those in City Corner but also much friendlier than any police station. Inside the bank is a reception counter and waiting room on the first floor and a safe on the second floor that’s perfect for recreating the Dr. Octopus robbery scene from Spider-Man 2 (but only with the appropriate Minifigs, of course). As with many city sets, Bank & Money Transfer has no shortage of stickers that you need to apply, but fortunately the only one that requires much of a steady hand is the vertical one that goes on the front sign.

The paucity of civilian buildings makes this set immediately attractive to city builders, but this set - with its myriad of vehicles and features - also makes it great for kids who actually play with their LEGO (imagine that). I suppose it’s a bit too much to hope for an office or other buildings to round out the town, but this set goes a very long way into bringing any city alive.

author: phipfwe76
title: A great set
review:
I had to get the City Bank the second I first saw it. It's a very unique (and perfect) addition to any city. The bank is a nice yellow which helps it stand out from the other buildings, and comes with a police car and very nice money truck. The build was pretty basic, aside from the money truck which is different and can carry a safe inside. The bank itself has an ATM out front and a counter for the teller, along with the big safe on the second floor. This set also comes with a cop and a criminal, which I think has been played out. My city is over-run by tons of each. Would've preferred the pieces for the cop car would've went to adding a drive-thru lane or something.

 

Overall, I love this set as every city has a bank and this one is very eye pleasing in my opinion. Fantastic addition to the City.

author: rj2uman
title: Easy Upgrade
review: Loving this set.  So easy to upgrade and add extra floors to!  You can take the side windows for the 3rd floor.  Most of the parts are easily found in any medium sized collection.  A rare thing in these days of overly specialized kits.  Also the armored car is pretty amazing, even if it is chunky and wide.  I didn't think that I would like the 6x6 tiles for the roof but after some handling and play time they really work alot better that I anticipated.  And the dirt bike and knapsack are genius!  Great set great price, easy to fit into any town and upgrade with additional levels.

author: Jacob_Wilson
title: LEGO City Police 3661 Bank & Money Transfer Special Edition - The Review
review: From my point of view this set should have been released years ago. We have finally got a Bank, something you need in the LEGO City Police Sets; So this means the Robbers have finally got somewhere to rob; Because the past there have never been anyway for the Robbers to rob. The set comes with: A Police Officer, City Bank Van Driver, Banker, Robber with a Crow Bar, the Unit 6 Police Car of all the 2011 Police Sets, the City Bank Money Transportation Van, a Motorbike for the Robber, City Bank building, lots of Money and Gold and 4 Green Bags of Money. Loads of great features in the this, (just been listed). The worst thing about this set is that it's a Special Edition Set, so it's Hard-to-Find but this one is not so bad because it's Exclusive to lego.com and Argos; I got this set from Argos. I am also thinking of getting the LEGO City Police 3648 Police Chase Special Edition Set, but you can only get it from lego.com!

author: memphis
title: First Lego set for my 4 year old son
review:
As my kid will be 4 soon, I decided to familiarize him with the Lego bricks. Bank & Money Transfer is first larger playset I bought and my son loves it. I paid 134pln (apx $40) and I think it's a very good price.

Pros

  • Great value for money (1 building, 3 vehicles, 4 minifigs)
  • Solid and sturdy, good for a small kid
  • Great playabilty

Cons

  • No doors in cars, (believe me, it's a great disappointment for a 4 year old kid)
  • No businessman minifig

It's great set, we having a great time playing with it. I'm totally recomending it.

author: gustavowizard
title: The Best City 2011 Set for Me!
review:
This set is excelent; in my opinion the best City set of 2011!

The Bank and the Armored MoneyCar are elegants, compact and full of resources, the top part opens for the thief, just neat.
It just fits nice on a desk or a table as on any stand. The piece colors are great, there are a good amount of sticks. The Bike is neat too and the Thief have a backpack to put the stolen cash :P. The Safe is Awesome and the place you put the cash and gold is neat too.
Here on Brasil lego is VERY expensive, like 3-5 times more expensive than US. But i got a 50% discount on this set so pay only 90 Reais (~51 US Dollars today), but this was the only one i got with same price as USA, others are much expensive.
The only little thing i did liked very much are the big pieces of the bank wall, i would prefer if they came with a bit more smaller pieces.

Sorry my english :)

author: Tyler_James
title: In a Lego City of cops and robbers, it makes sense to have a bank...
review:
I picked this set up in the Lego store in NYC back in 2010, and I was pretty excited to finally get it because a lot of stores were running out.  I think with tax it came out to be something like USD $65, which in my mind is a little too much for what you get here.  That said, there is a lot to like about this set, but I would recommend trying to find it used or discounted for something closer to 40 or 50, if that's possible.

Building Experience

This was an enjoyable set to put together, I especially liked the the armored truck and the way the bank was built.  When I was younger I really hated sets that limited your ability to play inside of them, so the fact that the top floor comes off easily is great.  Of course the more logical side of me always wondered how Lego people were supposed to get to that second floor without ladders or stairs, but I digress.  Each element of the set (armored truck, police car, each floor of the bank) came in a separate bag and with instructions, so that certainly makes it easier.  But as far as Lego sets go, this was not a hard one to put together or an especially surprising build in any way.  

Parts

One of the redeeming features of this set is the abundance of useful pieces, including the green suitcases, gold "bars," money tiles, and the bank teller/armored truck driver minifigs. I also am a big fan of the bike the robber.  The stickers included aren't too obtrusive; I did choose to not put any on the van or police car, but that's just me.  

Playability

This is probably one of the more "playable" sets I've purchased in the past couple years.  Having the pipe and roof opening for the bandit, in addition to the removable second floor, really makes the bank an interactive building.  Also, you get three vehicles, and while you probably don't need another police car, I thought this one was kind of cool looking (maybe a little more European?  I don't know though).  It's hard for me to really evaluate playability with a lot of sets because I look for different things now, but I can say without a doubt this is a good choice if playability is important to you.

Value for Money

Like I said earlier, I paid a total of USD 65 for this set.  I think that's far too high, but that is also the premium you end up paying when you are impulse shopping in NYC around Christmas.  But even at 50 (the current MSRP), I am hesitant to say this is a great value.  The cop and robber minifigs are not too valuable in my mind, and while there are some neat pieces, it just does not feel like a $50 set.  However, it makes a good addition to any existing city, and while I feel I paid too much, I am still glad I have it.  Definitely one of the better Lego City themed sets put out recently.

author: middleton83
title: The Bank that gives out money
review:
This set is a must have, I have seen no flaws in its amazing design. In the set you get a Police car (No. 6, which fits in with the rest of the 2011 police range), a red dirtbike (for the robber), a money truck (which carries all the money) and of course the bank (with a safe).

Now I will talk about each sub-build individually.

The first sub-build, which built the police car and dirtbike, with police officer and robber. The car was a really nice build as it has a little shelf behind the police officer (Personally somehwere to put his radio when he's driving), the dirtbike was a standard dirt bike build. The robber who has a rucksack has already stolen 2 bits of money (Though for some reason not already in the bank) looks a bit dim, but if he can rob a bank by himself, that's very imprssive, the police officer is a standard build with all police sets.

The second sub-build built the moeny truck, and security guard person. The truck is amazing, it could be used for so much more than money. The only downside to the truck is the holes at the sides of the wheels (Very hard to see), you don't want the money geting wet.

The third and final sub-build is the bank with bank worker. The bank has been laid out really well, and there isnt a cramped feel like other buildings. The ATM / Cash machine is a really nice feature, and because of how it is built it aslo means if the robber was to take it away, he would get a free clock. The safe is massive as it covers about half of the upper floor space. the robber can eneter the bank from a pipe on the side of the building and the roof.

Pros

  • 3 vehicles
  • 4 minifigures
  • Well built bank
  • The playability features

Cons

  • The price is a bit steep, but deffinetly worth it
  • No managers office

Now the final thing you should know is, Where did the criminal get the red dirtbike? He could have stolen it, but there are no places to buy dirtbikes in Lego City, perhaps it was imported. Only time will tell where he obtained it from.

author: Hobbythom
title: A must have for City lovers
review:
This set is without a doubt one of my favourite sets ever. You get a good amount of bricks for your money which build up in to three models (not counting the motor bike). I will give a short description of each.

Police car

This is actually the only thing I'm not a really big fan of. It just seems a bit long for a small car. But I guess for those who don't have a lot of policecars or the kids who prefer playability it's a decent catch. For me personally,  a normal car with a potential customer for the bank would have been nice.

Armoured Truck

Simply put a wonderful model. It looks heavy, sturdy and carries a respectable amount of loot for the crook. It's build up from a lot of parts. Furthermore, it could be stripped down to a wonderful template for any kind of delivery van.

The bank

The bank looks the part from the outside. It really is a sturdy construction which gives it a nice, tall and office-like look. Just like you'd expect from a bank. inside you'll find lots of details and great playability.

Overal

Great value for money, great set, highly recommended.

author: Lego600269
title: Very Good Set to add in the City
review:
Out of this set, I just like this set, period. There are 4 minifigures, 3 vehicles(a police car,a bank van,and a motorcycle), a bank, and a TON of useful bricks, like gold bars and money pieces.

Pros
  • The set is special edition
  • The security bank van is well made
  • Love the way the crook's face is
  • The ATM falls and breaks(good for robbery videos)
Cons
  • Some bricks are common
  • The building took me 3 hours
  • It would be better with another police car and police officer

Other things:
  • The van can turn into an airport van, with capacity to hold 4 suitcases
  • The van can also be turned into a police dog van, with the capacity to fit 2 dogs perfectly
  • If wanted, the bank can be more normal if the slide was removed

Grades:
Building:87
Parts:82
Playable:100
Money:95

Final Grade:91
